repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: This should adress #3612. I added a simple test case to ensure that the `__del__` methods is called when the cdef class is released.

comment_data.body:
Maybe "Python 3.4 made it possible for extension types to safely define finalizers for objects. When running a Cython module on Python 3.4 and higher you can add..."
then at the end "On Python <3.4 :meth:`__del__` will not be called".

Obviously `__del__` has existing as a Python concept for much longer and so my proposed wording tries to avoid that confusion.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -122,7 +122,12 @@ of the superclass will always be called, even if it is overridden.  This is in
 contrast to typical Python behavior where superclass methods will not be
 executed unless they are explicitly called by the subclass.
 
-.. Note:: There is no :meth:`__del__` method for extension types.
+Python 3.4 introduced the :meth:`__del__` method to allow for the safe

comment_data.body: OK, I did not know that. Let me just fix that...

+        # if instance was resurrected by finaliser, return

comment_data.body:
C89. And spelling :). And we don't need the extra braces since all of this is inside an `if … {}`
```suggestion
        code.putln("int resurrected;")
        code.putln("PyObject *etype, *eval, *etb;")
        code.putln("PyErr_Fetch(&etype, &eval, &etb);")
        code.putln("resurrected = PyObject_CallFinalizerFromDealloc(o);")
        code.putln("PyErr_Restore(etype, eval, etb);")
        # if instance was resurrected by finaliser, abort finalisation
        code.putln("if (resurrected) return;")
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1699,6 +1686,31 @@ def generate_dealloc_function(self, scope, code):
         if cdealloc_func_entry is None:
             code.putln("#endif")
 
+    def generate_finalizer_call(self, needs_gc, code):
+        code.putln("#if CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE")
+
+        if needs_gc:
+            finalised_check = '!_PyGC_FINALIZED(o)'
+        else:
+            finalised_check = (
+                '(!PyType_IS_GC(Py_TYPE(o)) || !_PyGC_FINALIZED(o))')
+        code.putln(
+            "if (unlikely("
+            "(PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x03080000 || __Pyx_PyType_HasFeature(Py_TYPE(o), Py_TPFLAGS_HAVE_FINALIZE))"
+            " && Py_TYPE(o)->tp_finalize) && %s) {" % finalised_check)
+        # if instance was resurrected by finaliser, return
+
+        code.putln("{")
+        code.putln("PyObject *etype, *eval, *etb;")
+        code.putln("PyErr_Fetch(&etype, &eval, &etb);")
+        code.putln("const int ressurected = PyObject_CallFinalizerFromDealloc(o);")
+        code.putln("PyErr_Restore(etype, eval, etb);")
+        code.putln("if (ressurected) return;")
+        code.putln("}")

comment_data.body:
I don't think this is a typo. In science, and probably other contexts, "iff …" commonly refers to "if, and only if, …"
```suggestion
            # delegate GC methods to its parent - iff the parent
```
This looks like `SyntheticSlot` would do the job.

         self.generate_set_slot_code(src, scope, code)
 
 
+class DelSlot(InternalMethodSlot):

comment_data.body: I'd add a check for `.is_special`, to make sure that `__del__` refers to the right kind of type slot method (and not an attribute or something else).

comment_data.body: Let's import the `gc` module globally.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,309 @@
+# mode: run
+
+cdef class nontrivial_del:
+    def __init__(self):
+        print("init")
+
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del")
+
+def test_del():
+    """
+    >>> test_del()
+    start
+    init
+    del
+    finish
+    """
+    print("start")
+    d = nontrivial_del()
+    d = None
+    import gc

comment_data.body: Could you use different global names for the different tests? Otherwise, if one test fails for some reason, and does not clean up its global, the instance might leak into the next test and make it fail as well, thus making it less clear what went wrong where.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,309 @@
+# mode: run
+
+cdef class nontrivial_del:
+    def __init__(self):
+        print("init")
+
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del")
+
+def test_del():
+    """
+    >>> test_del()
+    start
+    init
+    del
+    finish
+    """
+    print("start")
+    d = nontrivial_del()
+    d = None
+    import gc
+    gc.collect()
+    print("finish")
+
+
+cdef class del_and_dealloc:
+    def __init__(self):
+        print("init")
+
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del")
+
+    def __dealloc__(self):
+        print("dealloc")
+
+def test_del_and_dealloc():
+    """
+    >>> test_del_and_dealloc()
+    start
+    init
+    del
+    dealloc
+    finish
+    """
+    print("start")
+    d = del_and_dealloc()
+    d = None
+    import gc
+    gc.collect()
+    print("finish")
+
+
+cdef class del_with_exception:
+    def __init__(self):
+        print("init")
+
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del")
+        raise Exception("Error")
+
+def test_del_with_exception():
+    """
+    >>> test_del_with_exception()
+    start
+    init
+    del
+    finish
+    """
+    print("start")
+    d = nontrivial_del()
+    d = None
+    import gc
+    gc.collect()
+    print("finish")
+
+
+
+def test_nontrivial_del_with_exception():
+    """
+    >>> test_nontrivial_del_with_exception()
+    start
+    init
+    del
+    end
+    """
+    print("start")
+    def inner():
+        c = nontrivial_del()
+        raise RuntimeError()
+
+    try:
+        inner()
+    except RuntimeError:
+        pass
+
+    print("end")
+
+cdef class parent:
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del parent")
+
+class child(parent):
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del child")
+
+def test_del_inheritance():
+    """
+    >>> test_del_inheritance()
+    start
+    del child
+    finish
+    """
+    print("start")
+    c = child()
+    c = None
+    import gc
+    gc.collect()
+    print("finish")
+
+
+cdef class cy_parent:
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del cy_parent")
+
+    def __dealloc__(self):
+        print("dealloc cy_parent")
+
+class py_parent:
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del py_parent")
+
+class multi_child(cy_parent, py_parent):
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del child")
+
+def test_multiple_inheritance():
+    """
+    >>> test_multiple_inheritance()
+    start
+    del child
+    dealloc cy_parent
+    finish
+    """
+    print("start")
+    c = multi_child()
+    c = None
+    import gc
+    gc.collect()
+    print("finish")
+
+
+cdef class immortal:
+    def __del__(self):
+        global c
+        print("del")
+        c = self
+
+    def __dealloc__(self):
+        print("dealloc")
+
+def test_zombie_object():
+    """
+    >>> test_zombie_object()
+    start
+    del
+    del global
+    del
+    finish
+    """
+    global c
+    print("start")
+    i = immortal()
+    i = None
+    import gc
+    print("del global")
+    del c
+    gc.collect()
+    print("finish")
+
+
+# Same as above, but the member
+# makes the class GC, so it
+# is deallocated
+cdef class gc_immortal:
+    cdef object x
+
+    def __del__(self):
+        global c

+        print("init")
+

+
+def test_del_with_exception():
+    """
+    >>> test_del_with_exception()
+    start
+    init
+    del
+    finish
+    """
+    print("start")

+def test_nontrivial_del_with_exception():
+    """
+    >>> test_nontrivial_del_with_exception()
+    start
+    init
+    del
+    end

+    print("start")
+    def inner():
+        c = nontrivial_del()
+        raise RuntimeError()
+
+    try:
+        inner()
+    except RuntimeError:
+        pass
+
+    print("end")
+
+cdef class parent:
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del parent")
+
+class child(parent):
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del child")
+
+def test_del_inheritance():
+    """
+    >>> test_del_inheritance()
+    start
+    del child
+    finish
+    """
+    print("start")
+    c = child()
+    c = None
+    import gc
+    gc.collect()
+    print("finish")
+
+
+cdef class cy_parent:
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del cy_parent")
+
+    def __dealloc__(self):
+        print("dealloc cy_parent")
+
+class py_parent:
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del py_parent")
+
+class multi_child(cy_parent, py_parent):
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del child")
+
+def test_multiple_inheritance():
+    """
+    >>> test_multiple_inheritance()
+    start
+    del child
+    dealloc cy_parent
+    finish
+    """
+    print("start")
+    c = multi_child()
+    c = None
+    import gc
+    gc.collect()
+    print("finish")
+
+
+cdef class immortal:
+    def __del__(self):
+        global c
+        print("del")
+        c = self
+
+    def __dealloc__(self):
+        print("dealloc")
+
+def test_zombie_object():
+    """
+    >>> test_zombie_object()
+    start
+    del
+    del global
+    del
+    finish
+    """
+    global c
+    print("start")
+    i = immortal()
+    i = None
+    import gc
+    print("del global")
+    del c
+    gc.collect()
+    print("finish")
+
+
+# Same as above, but the member
+# makes the class GC, so it
+# is deallocated
+cdef class gc_immortal:
+    cdef object x
+
+    def __del__(self):
+        global c
+        print("del")
+        c = self
+
+    def __dealloc__(self):
+        print("dealloc")
+
+def test_gc_zombie_object():
+    """
+    >>> test_gc_zombie_object()
+    start
+    del
+    del global
+    dealloc
+    finish
+    """
+    global c
+    print("start")
+    i = gc_immortal()
+    i = None
+    import gc
+    print("del global")
+    del c
+    gc.collect()
+    print("finish")
+
+
+cdef class cdef_parent:
+    pass
+
+cdef class cdef_child(cdef_parent):
+    def __del__(self):
+        print("del")
+    def __dealloc__(self):
+        print("dealloc")
+
+def test_cdef_parent_object():
+    """
+    >>> test_cdef_parent_object()
+    start
+    del
+    dealloc
+    finish
+    """
+    print("start")
+    i = cdef_child()
+    i = None
+    import gc
+    gc.collect()
+    print("finish")
+

comment_data.body:
It's enough to do this once.
```suggestion
        slot_func_cname = scope.mangle_internal("tp_finalize")
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1553,6 +1554,27 @@ def generate_new_function(self, scope, code, cclass_entry):
         code.putln(
             "}")
 
+    def generate_del_function(self, scope, code):
+        tp_slot = TypeSlots.ConstructorSlot("tp_finalize", '__del__')
+        slot_func = scope.mangle_internal("tp_finalize")

comment_data.body: You can use `TypeSlots.get_slot_code_by_name("tp_finalize")` to get the slot code, rather than constructing the `Slot` instance here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1553,6 +1554,27 @@ def generate_new_function(self, scope, code, cclass_entry):
         code.putln(
             "}")
 
+    def generate_del_function(self, scope, code):

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
:meth:`__dealloc__`), permitting the use of Python operations
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -122,7 +122,13 @@ of the superclass will always be called, even if it is overridden.  This is in
 contrast to typical Python behavior where superclass methods will not be
 executed unless they are explicitly called by the subclass.
 
-.. Note:: There is no :meth:`__del__` method for extension types.
+Python 3.4 made it possible for extension types to safely define
+finalizers for objects. When running a Cython module on Python 3.4 and
+higher you can add a :meth:`__del__` method to extension types in
+order to perform Python cleanup operations. When the :meth:`__del__`
+is called the object is still in a valid state (unlike in the case of
+:meth:`__dealloc___`-ation), permitting the use of Python operations

comment_data.body:
I'm not 100% sure what's going on with PyPy, but I think the fact this slot is even set is breaking it. I'd change this line to

```
return """
#if CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE
%s
#else
    NULL
#endif
""" % InternalMethodSlot.slot_code(self, scope)
```

and that way avoid setting `tp_finalize` unless we plan to use it
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -503,6 +503,17 @@ def spec_value(self, scope):
         return self.slot_code(scope)
 
 
+class DelSlot(SyntheticSlot):
+    # For __del__ if defined
+    def __init__(self, slot_name, user_methods, default_value, **kwargs):
+        super(DelSlot, self).__init__(slot_name, user_methods, default_value, **kwargs)
+
+    def slot_code(self, scope):
+        if not scope.lookup_here("__del__"):
+            return 0
+        return InternalMethodSlot.slot_code(self, scope)

comment_data.body:
I don't think that's right. The version I suggested sets the slot to NULL when `CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE` isn't set while your version assumes that the slot doesn't exist (which will break the slots listed after it)

I admit that my version is really ugly though and there should probably be a better way to do it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1021,7 +1021,7 @@ def get_slot_code_by_name(scope, slot_name):
     EmptySlot("tp_weaklist"),
     EmptySlot("tp_del"),
     EmptySlot("tp_version_tag"),
-    DelSlot("tp_finalize", ["__del__"], "0", ifdef="PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x030400a1"),
+    DelSlot("tp_finalize", ["__del__"], "0", ifdef="PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x030400a1 && CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE"),

comment_data.body: I'd rather not have this part right here, but in a new option similar to `ifdef=`. `slot_code()` should return the plain value, `generate()` takes care of the C-level conditions. Maybe `used_ifdef=`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -503,6 +503,23 @@ def spec_value(self, scope):
         return self.slot_code(scope)
 
 
+class DelSlot(SyntheticSlot):
+    # For __del__ if defined
+    def __init__(self, slot_name, user_methods, default_value, **kwargs):
+        super(DelSlot, self).__init__(slot_name, user_methods, default_value, **kwargs)
+
+    def slot_code(self, scope):
+        if not scope.lookup_here("__del__"):
+            return 0
+        return """
+        #if CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE
+        %s
+        #else
+        NULL
+        #endif
+        """ % InternalMethodSlot.slot_code(self, scope)

comment_data.body: Another advantage right here: this can go away (and the whole method, actually), if the C conditions are handled in `generate()`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -503,6 +503,23 @@ def spec_value(self, scope):
         return self.slot_code(scope)
 
 
+class DelSlot(SyntheticSlot):
+    # For __del__ if defined
+    def __init__(self, slot_name, user_methods, default_value, **kwargs):
+        super(DelSlot, self).__init__(slot_name, user_methods, default_value, **kwargs)
+
+    def slot_code(self, scope):
+        if not scope.lookup_here("__del__"):

comment_data.body: @ax487 As a hint (since I think it was me that originally suggested putting this `#if` mess in `slot_code`): I think the suggestion is to handle it around https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/f4ce85ba8de0fc26a1e47d1bb6e0027ec95fe24a/Cython/Compiler/TypeSlots.py#L294
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -503,6 +503,23 @@ def spec_value(self, scope):
         return self.slot_code(scope)
 
 
+class DelSlot(SyntheticSlot):
+    # For __del__ if defined
+    def __init__(self, slot_name, user_methods, default_value, **kwargs):
+        super(DelSlot, self).__init__(slot_name, user_methods, default_value, **kwargs)
+
+    def slot_code(self, scope):
+        if not scope.lookup_here("__del__"):
+            return 0
+        return """
+        #if CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE
+        %s
+        #else
+        NULL
+        #endif
+        """ % InternalMethodSlot.slot_code(self, scope)

comment_data.body:
I've tried to solve this in https://github.com/cython/cython/commit/f7570d7b7bc8b5cac0ae7f567b99a9e3c5826521 (in the interests of getting this change finished).

I don't think I can push it to this PR myself so @scoder could you apply it (if it looks suitable)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -503,6 +503,23 @@ def spec_value(self, scope):
         return self.slot_code(scope)
 
 
+class DelSlot(SyntheticSlot):
+    # For __del__ if defined
+    def __init__(self, slot_name, user_methods, default_value, **kwargs):
+        super(DelSlot, self).__init__(slot_name, user_methods, default_value, **kwargs)
+
+    def slot_code(self, scope):
+        if not scope.lookup_here("__del__"):
+            return 0
+        return """
+        #if CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE
+        %s
+        #else
+        NULL
+        #endif
+        """ % InternalMethodSlot.slot_code(self, scope)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        tp_slot = TypeSlots.get_slot_by_name("tp_finalize", scope.directives)
```

(I think).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1628,6 +1629,27 @@ def generate_new_function(self, scope, code, cclass_entry):
         code.putln(
             "}")
 
+    def generate_del_function(self, scope, code):
+        tp_slot = TypeSlots.get_slot_by_name("tp_finalize")

comment_data.body: Right, that changed in master. Looks reasonable.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1628,6 +1629,27 @@ def generate_new_function(self, scope, code, cclass_entry):
         code.putln(
             "}")
 
+    def generate_del_function(self, scope, code):
+        tp_slot = TypeSlots.get_slot_by_name("tp_finalize")

comment_data.body:
I can't add the suggestion in the right place, but this also needs:

```
MethodSlot(destructor, "", "__del__", method_name_to_slot)
```
to be added just under
```
MethodSlot(destructor, "", "__dealloc__", method_name_to_slot)
```
for `__del__` to be recognised as a special method.

(I've tested this locally and the pep442_tp_finalize test passes - I think it was just lost in the merge of the big changes in TypeSlots.py)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1061,7 +1074,8 @@ def __init__(self, old_binops):
             EmptySlot("tp_weaklist"),
             EmptySlot("tp_del"),
             EmptySlot("tp_version_tag"),
-            EmptySlot("tp_finalize", ifdef="PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x030400a1"),
+            SyntheticSlot("tp_finalize", ["__del__"], "0", ifdef="PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x030400a1",
+                          used_ifdef="CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE"),

comment_data.body:
Right, that was originally added in this PR:
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/d695dce345cf298c4d660c30c2c64a10737c5593/Cython/Compiler/TypeSlots.py#L1010
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1061,7 +1074,8 @@ def __init__(self, old_binops):
             EmptySlot("tp_weaklist"),
             EmptySlot("tp_del"),
             EmptySlot("tp_version_tag"),
-            EmptySlot("tp_finalize", ifdef="PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x030400a1"),
+            SyntheticSlot("tp_finalize", ["__del__"], "0", ifdef="PY_VERSION_HEX >= 0x030400a1",
+                          used_ifdef="CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE"),

comment_data.body: Shouldn't this condition be aligned with the `used_ifdef` below? That uses `CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE`. However, the latter is also enabled for the limited API. That seems conflicting.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1628,6 +1629,27 @@ def generate_new_function(self, scope, code, cclass_entry):
         code.putln(
             "}")
 
+    def generate_del_function(self, scope, code):
+        tp_slot = TypeSlots.get_slot_by_name("tp_finalize", scope.directives)
+        slot_func_cname = scope.mangle_internal("tp_finalize")
+        if tp_slot.slot_code(scope) != slot_func_cname:
+            return  # never used
+
+        entry = scope.lookup_here("__del__")
+        if entry is None or not entry.is_special:
+            return  # nothing to wrap
+        slot_func_cname = scope.mangle_internal("tp_finalize")
+        code.putln("")
+
+        code.putln("#if !CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API")

comment_data.body: Yes I think so. It gives a compile error in the limited API as it is, but works with `#if CYTHON_USE_TP_FINALIZE`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1628,6 +1629,27 @@ def generate_new_function(self, scope, code, cclass_entry):
         code.putln(
             "}")
 
+    def generate_del_function(self, scope, code):
+        tp_slot = TypeSlots.get_slot_by_name("tp_finalize", scope.directives)
+        slot_func_cname = scope.mangle_internal("tp_finalize")
+        if tp_slot.slot_code(scope) != slot_func_cname:
+            return  # never used
+
+        entry = scope.lookup_here("__del__")
+        if entry is None or not entry.is_special:
+            return  # nothing to wrap
+        slot_func_cname = scope.mangle_internal("tp_finalize")
+        code.putln("")
+
+        code.putln("#if !CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API")

commit.message: Added PEP 442 implementation and test case
Disabled PEP 442 test for older python versions
Added fix to restore exception state after calling finalizer
Changed documentation according to the review
Fixed exception restoration for resurrected objects
Started working on generating a del function

Generated wrapped tp_finalize method

With exception clearing and restoration

Merge pull request #1 from da-woods/del

Generated wrapped tp_finalize method

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Added PEP 442 implementation and test case
